data.title: Monospacing broken by certain Unicode characters

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
NB: TextMate is the only editor I know that gets this right!

Many kinds of Unicode characters are wider than normal, some have narrower width;
in a monospace font, the width should **always** be fixed.

The fault in VSCode is that such wide/narrow Unicode characters throw off the spacing for the rest of the line -- making it impossible to get back to the same alignment as other lines! (tabs or otherwise)

TextMate displays all Unicode characters at fixed width regardless of their proportional width, including zero-width characters. This is the best behaviour for monospaced source code.

To avoid some level of confusion over zero-width characters (like Null, zero-width-joiner, bi-di codes &c.) being displayed at full width, whitespace codes could be used (such as when whitespace is visible) -- Unicode provides some visible symbols for non-visible characters, e.g. `␀` (0x2400)

![monospace_unicode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/142650/12066948/c6334f6e-afe8-11e5-99f0-71cefed03e3b.png)

So, ideally, what I'm asking for is:
- All characters, always the same width
- Better display of non-visible / zero-width characters if possible

I don't have access to TextMate at the moment, but you can use this file as a test, which was written in it: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Kroc/DOMTemplate/master/domtemplate.php

Kind regards,
Kroc Camen.

data.title: Allow to configure title bar information
data.body:
It would be great if we could configure the information that gets displayed in the title bar. I use ManicTime a lot, and it's hard to auto tag my activities when the title bar basically only displays the file name and root folder name. Having the full path to the file and the git branch name would be super helpful. 

For some other ideas, this VS plugin is super rad and affords complete control over what gets displayed in the title bar. https://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/2e8ebfe4-023f-4c4d-9b7a-d05bbc5cb239

data.title: launching electron app produces module not found
data.body:
hello:

the latest electron docs state that to run the application, one must `require('electron')`.  from the command line (osx), when I run my setup, it runs fine:

```
# yahoo, my app boots just fine via cmd line
cdieringer@Snapper-osx:~/node/coinstac$ ./node_modules/.bin/electron app/main/index.js --development --webpack --hotswap --loglevel=debugc
```

i am running the _latest_ electron as of the time of writing:

```
cdieringer@Snapper-osx:~/node/coinstac$ ./node_modules/.bin/electron --version
v0.36.2
```

when I try to launch this from vscode, it craps out, stating electron cannot be found.  my launch config, AFIK, should be ~same!

``` json
        {
            "name": "Debug",
            "type": "node",
            "program": "app/main/index.js",
            "stopOnEntry": true,
            "args": ["--hotswap", "--development", "--webpack", "--loglevel=debug"],
            "cwd": ".",
            "runtimeExecutable": "node_modules/.bin/electron",
            "runtimeArgs": ["--nolazy"],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "development",
                "COINS_ENV": "development",
                "ATOM_SHELL_INTERNAL_RUN_AS_NODE": "0"
            },
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        },
```

data.body:
Hi all,
I have a VSCode extension with debugger contribution and I want to add also custom commands to the extension. AFAIK, extension with debug adapter will be loaded in a separate process and will be activated when a debug session is started. 
Is it possible to add custom commands in the extension and configure them also to be activation events?

data.title: Enable specifying installation directories in npm.sh

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello,

Currently you are unable to specify installation paths for node modules used by Code via `scripts/npm.sh`, only the architecture. This is an issue for package management systems on Linux where specific packages may "own" a set of files or directories, and thus produces conflicts on the system when multiple packages attempt to own the same set of files.

I'm proposing the following options be added to `npm.sh`:

`--installdir=DIR`: This would enable you to specify a general installation directory:
- Beneficial for build systems that use isolated install directories (where the contents of it are then considered the contents of a binary package) away from the build directories.

`--node-modules=DIR`: This would enable you to specify **the root** of where you want node modules to be installed.
- Resolves potential file conflicts for packages and pollution of global node_modules.

Examples:

`--installdir=/var/ypkg-root/install/vscode/`: This would be the root of the file system. Installation of binaries such as those placed in `/usr/bin` would begin with the installdir, so it is conceivable that the directory would for the binaries would then be `/var/ypkg-root/install/vscode/usr/bin`.
- Note: This would only be on the isolated build system, the final contents installed on the user's system would still be /usr/bin, this would just specify where to install things on build-time.
- Defaults to `/`
- Sets something like $installdir (used below).

`--node-modules=$installdir/usr/share/vscode/`: This would install node modules to a `node_module` folder in `/usr/share/vscode`. This keeps it isolated from any `npm` or `nodejs` system packages and files. Atom does something similar, with installing things to (_for example_) `/usr/share/atom/resources/...`

Thoughts?

data.title: CPU usage skyrockets when holding down an input button

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code Version: 0.10.6 (dcb02458)
OS: Windows 10

How to reproduce:  
- Open task manager  
- Open a new file  
- Hold down a letter or a space bar or enter  

Arrow button also causes this, but cursor needs to move i think. So if you add some text and hold down an arrow key, it will produce the same issue.

CPU usage goes from ~0 to ~33% for me (i5 cpu). 

From my limited knowledge, i can assume 2 things: 
This is either fixable by making the whatever code executes when cursor changes position be executed only if cursor didn't change position for 100-200 milliseconds 
**or**
Input handling is not limited by "fps", so the app gets overwhelmed

data.title: workspace.applyEdit fails in git view
data.body:
I have a code action that performs a WorkspaceEdit which works just fine in the normal view but fails in the diff view.

Code:

``` javascript
let edit = new vscode.WorkspaceEdit();
edit.replace(uri, range, replacementText);
vscode.workspace.applyEdit(edit);
```

Message:
TypeError: i.getModel(...).getAssociatedResource is not a function

Stack:
TypeError: i.getModel(...).getAssociatedResource is not a function\n    at Object.a [as finish](file:///C:/Program Files %28x86%29/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:36:9471)\n    at Object.d [as bulkEdit](file:///C:/Program Files %28x86%29/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:36:9143)\n    at e.applyWorkspaceEdit (file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:61:18416)\n    at t.e.handle (file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:52:3220)\n    at a (file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:38:12357)\n    at Object.h.handle (file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:38:12921)\n    at file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:67:5098\n    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (file:///C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:67:7608)\n    at emitTwo (events.js:87:13)\n    at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:172:7)

data.title: Markdown preview doesn't correctly parse escaped parenthesis
data.body: For example, consider the following URL: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/f7dy01k1(v=vs.110).aspx This URL has two parentheses in them. To be able to use this URL in a Markdown link, we have to escape the parentheses by prefixing them with a backslash: `[ildasm](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/f7dy01k1\(v=vs.110\).aspx)` However, the Markdown preview doesn't correctly parse these links:

I find this rather annoying as I have my own theme that I like to use.  I compiled my TextMate theme and everything ported over okay using `yo code` besides the multiline comment colors.  This theme works correctly in Sublime Text and TextMate, it's just Visual Studio Code that gives me an issue.

Is this a bug?  Is there a way to turn this off?

data.title: Thread exited event ignored
data.body:
Even though clearly an thread event with `reason: "exited"` is sent, VS Code does not update the UI to remove the exited thread:

![threads bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/12044480/5a48b016-ae92-11e5-883e-ca2f3ec47fed.gif)

last communication:

```
-> continueRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 21,
  command: 'continue',
  arguments: { threadId: 2 } }

<- continueResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 21,
  command: 'continue',
  success: true }

<- threadEvent
ThreadEvent {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'event',
  event: 'thread',
  body: { reason: 'exited', threadId: 2 } }
```

When a stack frame inside the dead thread is clicked VS Code tries to request the variables inside a thread that doesn't exist anymore.

Even weirder, the threads even keep showing even after the debug session ended:
![threads ui bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/12044454/e7b0af90-ae91-11e5-8d49-767bdccaa41c.png)

data.title: buffer newly created breakpoints until initialize request is received
data.body:
A debug adapter is free to request persisted breakpoints at any time by sending an "initialize" request. If another breakpoint is created before the "initialize" request has arrived, the breakpoint is directly sent to the adapter without waiting for the "initialize" request. This is a bug. We should buffer these breakpoints and send them to the adapter only upon receipt of the "initialize".

cc @felixfbecker

data.title: Break reason is shared between threads
data.body:
If one thread breaks on exception, and the other breaks on a breakpoint, whatever reason came last will always be what is shown in the UI.

![threads issue demo gif](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/12044260/cbce6464-ae8e-11e5-9c65-b1aca96d717c.gif)

data.title: VS Code does not honor success: false for VariableRequests

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
A bug I picked up during development. This is an screenshot showing how VS Code displays an error that was send through `sendErrorResponse` as a result for the variable, when it should really show an error message for the user.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/12044046/8d1a58de-ae8b-11e5-9c1f-15fe50d19197.png)

Here are my communication logs:

```
-> variablesRequest
{ type: 'request',
  seq: 10,
  command: 'variables',
  arguments: { variablesReference: 1 } }

<- variablesResponse
Response {
  seq: 0,
  type: 'response',
  request_seq: 10,
  command: 'variables',
  success: false,
  message: 'request \'variables\': test',
  body: 
   { error: 
      { id: 123,
        format: 'request \'variables\': test',
        showUser: true } } }
```

data.title: Feature negotiation between debug adapters and Code
data.body: Some debug adapters may not support all features (that you add in the future). For example, php-debug does not support breaking on caught exceptions. There needs to be a way to notify VS Code that this feature should be disabled (greyed out) for the user. (low priority)
